metadata.title: Labrum Lesions, Shoulder  Conservative Management
anatomical location body part affected: Glenohumeral joint, glenoid labrum, humeral head, rotator cuff tendons, biceps tendon, glenohumeral ligaments
description: The glenoid labrum is a ring of cartilage that surrounds the glenoid fossa and improves the fit of the humeral head. The superior part of the labrum is more mobile, whereas the interior part is considered the “anchor.” The superior and anterosuperior portions of the labrum have less vascularity compared with other regions. Blood is supplied to the labrum via the suprascapular, circumflex scapular, and posterior humeral arteries(8)
The long head of the biceps brachii inserts into the superior labrum. Labrum lesions can result from repetitive movements (i.e., atraumatic) or from acute trauma(8)

Classification(9,10) –A Bankart lesion occurs during anterior shoulder dislocation and involves tearing of the inferior labrum and the inferior glenohumeral ligament –A posterior lesion involves tearing of the posterior portion of the labrum –The superior labrum from anterior to posterior (SLAP) lesion involves tearing of the superior portion of the labrum -Classification of SLAP lesions(9,10) -Type I – Degeneration of the superior labrum without damage to the biceps attachment -Type II – Separation of the superior labrum from the glenoid with disruption of the biceps tendon attachment -Type III – Degeneration with a bucket-handle tear of the superior labrum without disruption of the biceps tendon attachment -Type IV – A bucket-handle  tear of the superior labrum with disruption of the biceps tendon attachment -Types I–IV  are accepted by most researchers. Types V–X  have been suggested by additional researchers(11) -Type V – A Bankart lesion with disruption of the biceps tendon attachment and anterior-inferior labral lesion -Type VI – Disruption of the biceps tendon attachment associated with a superiorflap tear of the labrum -Type VII – The lesion extends anteriorly to the middle glenohumeral ligament and is associated with disruption of the biceps tendon attachment -Type VIII – SLAP lesion with posterior labral extension -Type IX: pan-labral  lesion with circumferential involvement  -Type X: SLAP lesion with associated posterior-inferior  labral lesion (reverse Bankart) -SLAP lesions may occur concurrently with Bankart lesions, posterior labral injuries, or rotator cuff disorders(4) -Overhead athletes are more likely to have a posterior type II SLAP tear, while traumatic injuries more often cause an anterior type II SLAP tear(9) -Variations in anatomy in the labrum and biceps tendon affect the relationship between both structures.(8) These include: -labrum attachments to glenoid rim with broad middle glenohumeral (GH) ligament -sublabral recess – gap below biceps anchor -sublabral foramen -Buford complex – absence of anterosuperior labral tissue, presence of thickening middle GH ligament -Although 50% of National Football League combine recruits report a history of shoulder injuries, SLAP injuries account for only 3.1% of shoulder injuries in this group.(6) A 2021 review reports that there has been a consistent increase in the diagnosis of symptomatic SLAP tears in recent years.(9) Most recent research (2016 and later) on labral lesions is on SLAP injuries and especially in athletes -ICD-10  codes -S43.43 Superior glenoid labrum lesion -M24.41 Recurrent dislocation, shoulder -M25.3 other instability of joint -M75.8 other shoulder lesions –(ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes) -Reimbursement:  No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified -Presentation/signs and symptoms -SLAP injuries tend to be in overhead athletes or middle-aged  workers(8) -Athletes often present following injury, reporting pain with overhead activities or throwing, “clicking/clunking” in the affected shoulder, aching of the shoulder, feeling of instability in the shoulder, a “catching” sensation, and/or a feeling that they “cannot trust” their shoulder. Patients will often report their arm feeling “dead”(8) -ROM usually is normal, though pain may be present with full forward flexion and end-range external rotation -Concomitant shoulder injuries can be present, including glenohumeral instability, rotator cuff tears, and internal impingement(8) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
presentation signs and symptoms: -SLAP injuries tend to be in overhead athletes or middle-aged  workers(8) -Athletes often present following injury, reporting pain with overhead activities or throwing, “clicking/clunking” in the affected shoulder, aching of the shoulder, feeling of instability in the shoulder, a “catching” sensation, and/or a feeling that they “cannot trust” their shoulder. Patients will often report their arm feeling “dead”(8) -ROM usually is normal, though pain may be present with full forward flexion and end-range external rotation -Concomitant shoulder injuries can be present, including glenohumeral instability, rotator cuff tears, and internal impingement(8) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Labrum lesions often occur as a result of a traumatic incident, including a fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH), directblow to or fall on the shoulder, a sudden pull or other overhead motion (trying to lift an object or trying to grab/hang fromsomething to prevent a fall)(9)

In the cocking phase of throwing, the arm is in abduction and external rotation, which puts force on the posterior labrum.Also, if there is a posterior-inferior  capsular contracture with a resulting deficit in internal rotation, there can be increasedshear force on the posterior-superior  labrum(8)
pathogenesis: Pathogenesis may vary significantly based on mechanism of injury. In traumatic incidents, the humeral head often israpidly accelerated into the labrum and sometimes out of the glenoid fossa. This force can result in a tear to the labrum atthe point of contact of the humerus, with the location varying depending on the direction of the humeral head movement.For example, a FOOSH may result in a posterior or posterior-inferior  labrum tear or detachment as the humeral head ispushed anterior to posterior when the hand hits the ground, and the force travels through the arm to the shoulder
risk factors: Participation in certain activities may increase the risk of a labrum lesion, including weight lifting, throwing sports (e.g.,baseball) , sports with overhead activities (e.g., swimming, baseball, volleyball), contact sports, rock climbing/bouldering(8)–Overhead sporting activities involve the greatest risk for SLAP injuries(8)
Shoulder instability, previous shoulder injuries, or occupations requiring repetitive use of the shoulder may also increase

overall contraindications precautions: Patients with labrum lesions should avoid painful/exacerbating activities such as weight lifting (especially bench press, overhead press/military press), contact sports, and other activities that may result in further damage to the shoulder
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Many patients have experienced direct shoulder trauma, but onset may be insidious secondary to repetitive overuse of the shoulder. Is there a reproducible, painful, audible pop? Does the shoulder click, lock, or catch (common with labrum tears)?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Patients often report to the healthcare provider after a traumatic injury, although they may delay for several weeks before obtaining medical evaluation Medical management may include reduction for dislocation, immobilization, and activity modification
surgical management: Surgical management: If patient fails to improve with conservative therapy (usually a trial of 612  weeks), labral repairs (including Bankart/SLAP repairs, biceps tenodesis/tenotomy), labral debridement, and glenohumeral stabilization may be required.(3)The National Athletic Trainers’ Association recommends that conservative treatment be attempted for 3 to 6 months before surgical treatment is considered(11)
There has been an increase in the use of biceps tenodesis to treat SLAP injuries in older patients and in SLAP repairs with anchors in younger patients(8)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications have been prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effective? May include analgesics and NSAIDs
diagnostic tests completed: There are numerous injuries that may occur in the shoulder with signs/symptoms similar to those of labrum lesions. Comprehensive medical assessment may include MRI (with gadolinium) and diagnostic arthroscopy.(3)MR arthrography(5) has been found to be effective in diagnosing labral damage
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Ask patient to describe the primary aggravating activity. Aggravating factors may include overhead activity, throwing, and forward flexion
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Patients may describe symptoms as clicking/clunking, aching, a feeling of instability in the shoulder, catching, or a feeling that they cannot trust their shoulder
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much )
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to the condition. Does the patient have to alter the sleep position (e.g., sleep upright or on unaffected shoulder, rest arm on a pillow) as a result of this condition? Does the patient have increased pain at night?Note any use of supplemental oxygen or need for ventilation
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __  -If Yes, describe __________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there a history of shoulder injuries, prior shoulder pain, or previous dislocations? Any history of motor vehicle accidents? Neck or upper extremity injuries?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in overhead sports? Does the patient participate in contact sports? Does the patient participate in weight training? Overhead activities or throwing often are reported
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Are there any reported limitations in ability to complete ADLs (e.g., upper extremity dressing)?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Complete a general assessment as indicated with a focus on the items listed below
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess if injury is secondary to a fall –Berg Balance Scale
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Distal pulses should be normalThe upper extremity dermatome scan should be normalAssess as indicated (e.g., FIM, Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand [DASH])
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for deviations or decreased safety if injury is secondary to fall (e.g., Functional Gait Assessment[FGA]) Joint integrity and mobility –Perform special testing described below under Special tests specific to diagnosis , below –Additionally, joint laxity testing using anterior, posterior, and inferior drawer testing may be performed
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength (using manual muscle testing [MMT]) of shoulder movements in flexion, abduction, adduction, and internal and external rotation. Compare results to unaffected shoulder. The patient with an acute injury may have strength limitations secondary to pain or precautions, but those with older injuries may have no strength deficits
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess for tenderness of the rotator cuff tendons to assist in ruling out impingement/tendinitis
Inspect shoulder girdle and scapular musculature for atrophy and deformity (including winged scapula) compared to the contralateral shoulder
Assess surface anatomy of acromioclavicular, scapulothoracic, and sternoclavicular joints compared to uninvolved side

Following an acute injury, mild, generalized edema of the shoulder may be present •Pain:  Assess for provocation of pain with active ROM, resisted movements, and exacerbating activities. Pain with end-range flexion and overhead movements is common. Movements that cause the humeral head to compress the labral lesion will also be painful (for example, supine bench pressing in an individual with a posterior labrum lesion). Pain can be reported using visual analog scales (V AS)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess the cervical and thoracic spine, clavicles, scapulae, and shoulders for bilateral symmetry and general posture
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Measure (goniometric measurements) active and passive ROM to assess function of the rotator cuff and shoulder joint. Assess scapular and clavicular mobility. ROM following a labrum lesion usually is within normal limits
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexes as indicated, which should be normal following an isolated labrum lesionAssess limitation in ADLs and IADLS, including self-care, work-related,  and leisure activities secondary to shoulder pain/instability. Objective tests include the Barthel Index and DASH
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: –Sulcus sign – With patient seated, therapist provides a caudal directed force to humerus. A positive test consists of the observation of a “sulcus” or “step-off”  deformity above the humeral head. This test indicates shoulder instability –Dynamic shear test – Patient is standing, arm is placed in an arc of 80–120°  while physical therapist applies anteriorly directed force on the shoulder. Positive tests elicit pain in superior and posterior directions -Researchers found the dynamic labral shear test (DLST) to be sensitive but not specific in diagnosing SLAP lesions without concomitant injury in the shoulder(7) –Biceps load test – Patient in supine, arm abducted to 90°, and forearm supinated. The arm is then externally rotated. External rotation is stopped if apprehension occurs with external rotation. The patient is then asked to flex the elbow while the examiner resists elbow flexion. If apprehension remains the same or worsens, this is a positive test for a SLAP lesion. In a variation of this test, the biceps load test II, the arm is elevated to 120° and maximally externally rotated with the elbow flexed to 90°. Elbow flexion is then resisted; if this elicits pain, the test is positive for a SLAP lesion. In clinical studies, sensitivity ranged from 89.7% to 90.9% and specificity was 96.9%(1) –Compression-rotation  test – With patient in supine, shoulder is abducted to 90˚ with elbow flexed to 90˚; compression force applied and then rotated to trap torn labrum. A catch or snap may be felt –Apprehension test – the shoulder is moved passively into maximum external rotation while in abduction; when forward pressure is applied to the posterior aspect of the humeral head, the patient complains of shoulder pain and suddenly becomes apprehensive –Kim test – With the patient seated and the arm abducted to 90°, the examiner elevates the arm 45° while applying an inferior and posterior force to the proximal arm. If the patient has sudden posterior shoulder pain, the test is positive for a posteroinferior labral lesion –Internal rotation resistance strength test - apparent weakness on strength testing of internal versus external rotation of the arm, when held in 90° of abduction and 80° to 85° of external rotation –Jerk test – The patient is seated with his or her arm internally rotated and abducted 90°, elbow extended. The examiner grasps the elbow and loads the humerus proximally. The arm is then adducted in the horizontal plane. A sudden jerk or clunk indicates a posteroinferior labrum lesion –Crank test – With the patient seated, the affected shoulder is elevated to 160° in the scapular plane. The joint is loaded along the axis of the humerus by the examiner with one hand, while the other hand rotates the humerus. A positive test for glenoid labrum tear is identified either by pain (with or without clicking) or reproduction of the patient’s symptoms, usually while externally rotating the humerus.(1) The test should be repeated in supine position –Relocation (Jobe’s) test – With the patient supine, the shoulder is positioned in abducted and maximal externally rotated position. Posteriorly directed force is exerted on the proximal humerus. Pain on release of the posterior force is a positive test for labrum tear –Anterior slide test – With the patient seated and hand on hip, an anterior force is exerted on the elbow while proximal stabilization is provided. Reproduction of pain or noise is considered positive –O’Brien’s active compression test – The patient is standing with the affected arm flexed to 90°. The arm is then adducted 10–15°  and internally rotated. A downward force is then applied to the arm. The palm is then supinated and the maneuver repeated. A positive test for labrum tear is identified by pain/clicking “inside” the shoulder during the first maneuver that is relieved or eliminated by the second –It is important to note that although special tests for the labral may not be sensitive and specific individually, grouped together multiple positive tests can help indicate labral pathology(11) -According to guidelines of the National Athletic Trainers’ Association the following test combinations may be(11) -anterior-slide  test with a history of popping, clicking and catching -the compression-rotation,  apprehension, and Yergason tests -the compression-rotation,  apprehension, and biceps load tests -Authors of a 2019 reviewrecommended the combination of the biceps load I and II tests with O’Brien’s test, reporting sensitivity of 0.992–0.999  and a specificity of 0.992–0.999(12) –DASH Outcome Measure or other index -For additional information on the DASH, see Clinical Review…Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) ;T903177

contraindications precautions: Hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)
Cold may be counterproductive if used to facilitate muscle relaxation and reduce pain in patients who do not tolerate the modality
Over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
Over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy
In an area with infection or bleeding
If a tumor or malignancy is present in the area
In the area of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis
Over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia
Individuals who cannot communicate effectively (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier)
Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Therapeutic exercises should be performed with careful avoidance of irritation of existing symptoms, substitution patterns, or signs/symptoms of clicking, apprehension, or dislocation

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Pain and instability in the affected shoulder and inability to participate in overhead activities, contact sports, and other activities. A trial of conservative treatment, including physical therapy, is suggested unless activity modification is not possible due to athletic demands(25)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Biceps tendinitis/tear Ligamentous laxity (e.g., coracohumeral ligament, glenohumeral ligament) Rotator cuff tear/impingement Peripheral nerve entrapment Cervical radiculopathy  Recurrent shoulder dislocation Multidirectional instability (MDI)
prognosis: Authors of a 2020 systematic review reported that 93% of athletes return to sport and 3 of 4 athletes return to previous level of sport participation after SLAP intervention (conservative and surgical)(13) –The authors suggest that there is little guidance in the literature to assist with the decision regarding surgery for SLAP –The authors were critical of the literature,finding insufficient delineation between return to sport and return to sport at previous level and also not enough research on career longevity after SLAP injury
Middle-aged  workers with SLAP lesions often respond to conservative treatment(8)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physician if pain and instability persist after conservative management has been tried. Time frames for conservative management mentioned in the literature range from 6 weeks to 6 months –Surgical treatment for labral debridement or repair often is required to resolve symptoms, restore shoulder stability, and facilitate a return to previous function/athletics –Overhead-throwing  athletes and young active individuals with a type II SLAP tear will benefit from arthroscopic repair –Older patients may benefit from biceps tenodesis or tenotomy as well(8) –Surgical repair of the labrum often is indicated after traumatic injuries(8) -Surgical arthroscopy may include capsular shift, capsular plication -Surgical repair of inferior labral tears combined with aggressive physical therapy often results in return to sport at previous levels –Additionally, bicep tenodesis has become the preferred surgical option for failed SLAP repairs(8) -Type I SLAP tears tend to have less successful surgical outcomes. Some studies suggest that SLAP repairs should not be performed on individuals over age 40
treatment summary: It is suggested that physical therapy during conservative treatment and after surgery should focus on correcting scapular dyskinesis and posterior capsular contracture(8)

Guidelines of the National Athletic Trainers’ Association suggest that rehabilitation should include exercises that address deficits in shoulder internal rotation, total arc of motion, and horizontal-adduction  ROM, as wellas periscapular and glenohumeral neuromuscular control, muscle strength, and endurance(11)

There is a lack of randomized controlled studies investigating the efficacy of rehabilitation for this condition –Pain management and strengthening are the main therapy interventions recommended -Analgesics and NSAIDs may be used for pain/inflammation control -A comprehensive shoulder rehabilitation program that includes exercises for the rotator cuff is recommended to increase shoulder joint stability -The rehabilitation treatment plan should also involve patient education on the correction of faulty techniques and sports training errors, as well as discussion of acceptable approaches to relative rest and activity modification . desired outcomes: Restored functional mobility, as indicated; ability to perform daily activities and participate in sports–FIM–DASH–Barthel Index–ASES Shoulder Score(4)–Kerlan-Jobe  Orthopedic Clinic Score (KJOC)(4)

maintenance or prevention: Patients should continue to participate in a comprehensive shoulder and scapular stabilization strengthening program and should avoid exacerbating activities if they do not undergo surgical repair or debridement
